comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Possibly Florence Provost Batterton (1873-1922), wife of J. M. Batterton (1860-1928) of Kentucky? www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=40864370

comment.author: 76208917@N06
comment._content: This is a portrait of my Great-grandmother . Born Florence Josephine Kelley, she married Clarence E. Smith in1893. After his death in1910 she married Mr.(JM) Batterton. Her daughter was Mrs. Julian Lake Nugent, born Beatrice Provost Smith. Florence died in 1923.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: spider1906:  Can you tell us anything about why your great-grandmother might have been the subject of this photograph in the Bain New Service collection?  Also, how did you find her here on Flickr?  (I'm very curious!)

comment.author: 76208917@N06
comment._content: A few months ago I was researching my father's family. I came upon a link that said there were pictures of my grandmother in the library of congress. I tried to access the pictures but did not have any luck.  I received an e-mail from caroline a few months later saying she had a link to one of the pictures. She had found my message in a Freeman Report asking about my family and their connection to John Arbuckle the owner of the Arbuckle coffee Company in which my Great Grandfather William Van Rensselaer Smith had an interest.My Grandmother was Mrs. Julian Lake Nugent. Upon looking at the picture on the photo stream to the right of my Grandmother I noticed the Name Batterton. I enlarged the photo and recognized it as my Great grandmother from other pictures I have of her.

comment.author: 76208917@N06
comment._content: On Feb 14 1915 my grandmother laid the cornerstone to the new Brooklyn YMCA dedicated to her father Clarence E Smith. My Great great grandmother Roxie Maria Smith gave 500,000 dollars to have the new YMCA in Clarence's name. My great Grandmother Florence  Batterton was probably there as well.

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: @pennyrichardsca -- As spider1906 conjectures, both Mrs. James Madison Batterton, who was the former Mrs. Clarence E. Smith, and Mrs. Julian L. Nugent took part in the dedication ceremonies of the new Y.M.C.A. Clarence E. Smith Memorial Building, as reported in this January 24, 1915, society page in The New York Herald.   Mrs. Batterton hosted a bridge party for Mrs. Julian L. Nugent, while she was staying at the Waldorf-Astoria as the guest of her grandmother, Mrs. William Van Rensselaer Smith The memorial gift was announced in July, 1913, and many details are included in this New York Times article.

comment.author: 76208917@N06
comment._content:
Thank you for your articles.There was one that I had not seen. I knew so little from my father.
So many awful things followed in the next 16 or so years My father and my Uncle were badly scared with  the turn of events.
